Headline: Riots over privatization in Cochabamba, Bolivia
Description: Massive protests, riots, and violence result from efforts to privatize the water system of Cochabamba, Bolivia.

Headline: Terrorist drill gets out of hand in California
Description: A drill simulating a terrorist attack on the Nacimiento Dam in Monterey County, California got out of hand when two radio stations reported it as a real attack.

Headline: Kenyans battle monkeys for drought relief
Description: A clash between villagers and thirsty monkeys leaves eight apes dead and ten villagers wounded. The duel starts after water tankers bring water to a drought-stricken area and monkeys desperate for water attack the villagers.

Headline: Australian hacker causes sewage spills
Description: In Queensland, Australia, police arrest a man for using a computer and radio transmitter to take control of the Maroochy Shire wastewater system and release sewage into parks, rivers, and property.

Headline: Riots in northern China
Description: Civil unrest erupts over use and allocation of water from Baiyang Lake, the largest natural lake in northern China. Several people die in riots by villagers in July 2000 in Shandong after officials cut off water supplies. In August 2000, six die when officials in the southern province of Guangdong blow up a water channel to prevent a neighboring county from diverting water.

Headline: Regional drought heightens tensions in Ethiopia and Kenya
Description: The Ethiopian government says that regional drought worsens traditional conflicts at watering points and over access to pasture. The tensions are heightened by the presence of the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), an Ethiopian armed opposition group said to be operating from Kenyan territory near the common border.

Headline: Aqueduct in Colombia is attacked.
Description: A bombing attempt occurs at an aqueduct in Colombia. The bomb does not detonate. The National Liberation Army is suspected in the attempt.

Headline: Water company is bombed to demand release of prisoners
Description: A water company office in Ustaritz, France is damaged by a bomb thought to be placed in support of a group called the Basque Fatherland and Freedom (aka ETA). The attackers leave writing on the wall in the building demanding the release of ETA prisoners.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Luxury home burned to protest impact on watershed
Description: The Earth Liberation Front (ELF) claims responsibility for setting a luxury home under construction on fire. Their written statement says they targeted the home because of its location in the Lake Monroe watershed, a drinking water supply for the town of Bloomington, Indiana, which is in jeopardy from urban sprawl.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Settlers attack a village in Palestine, injuring civilians and cutting water supply
Description: In a village in Palestine, three Palestinians are injured by gunshots from Israeli settlers. The same settlers also cut the water supply to the village by damaging the pipes.
Sources: RAND Database of Worldwide Terrorism Incidents 2018

Headline: Israeli settlers are accused of intentionally releasing sewage to contaminate Palestinian agricultural fields in the West Bank
Description: Israeli settlers from Efrat are blamed for deliberately releasing sewer water into Palestinian agricultural fields in the West Bank.

Headline: Water supply tank for a condominium in Singapore deliberately contaminated
Description: A water supply tank is deliberately poisoned with kerosene and turpentine. Residents of the condominium complex in Singapore discover the contamination from the odor of their water.

Headline: A man is arrested for attempted poisoning of community water supply in Turkey
Description: A man is arrested for attempted poisoning of the water supply for the village of Kurusaray, Turkey.

Headline: Water storage facility is destroyed
Description: Eritrea accuses Ethiopia of bombing the Red Sea port at Assab, saying several bombs are dropped on Assab, destroying a water storage facility on the outskirts of the town.

Headline: Students riot to protest water shortages
Description: Students riot to protest water shortages in Kenya.

Headline: Moroccean army destroys wells
Description: Units of the Moroccan army destroy the wells situated in the municipalities of Guelta and Boujdour. Citizens usually use these wells to provide water for their sheep in the summer.

Headline: Clashes between rioters and police over water shortages
Description: Sudanese rioters who are protesting against the failure of schools to reopen as well as water and electricity shortages clash with police who intervene to quell the riot. At least one student is killed and many are injured.

Headline: Palestinians destroy water supply to Israeli settlements
Description: Palestinians destroy water supply pipelines to the West Bank settlement of Yitzhar and to Kibbutz Kissufim. The Agbat Jabar refugee camp near Jericho disconnects from its water supply after Palestinians loot and damage local water pumps. Palestinians accuse Israel of destroying a water cistern, blocking water tanker deliveries, and attacking materials for a wastewater treatment project.

Headline: Unrest over shortages in Pakistan
Description: Civil unrest over severe water shortages caused by the long-term drought. Protests began in March and April and continued into summer. Riots, four bombs in Karachi (June 13), one death, 12 injuries, 30 arrests. Ethnic conflicts as some groups "accuse the government of favoring the populous Punjab province [over Sindh province] in water distribution.'

Headline: Water cut off in Macedonian conflict
Description: Water flow to Kumanovo (population 100,000), Macedonia cut off for 12 days in conflict between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian forces. Valves of Glaznja and Lipkovo Lakes damaged.
